revised_title: Determination of the Difference of Meridians of the Royal Observatories of Greenwich and Paris
tldr: The author, Thomas Henderson, investigates the difference of meridians between the Royal Observatories of Greenwich and Paris using rocket explosions as signals. He calculates the rates of the chronometers used at Lignieres and Fairlight, and determines the most probable value of the difference of longitude to be 91° 2' 1s. This study highlights the importance of accurate timekeeping and precise observations in determining the Earth's meridians.
